Abstract: Recent advancements in imaging spectroscopy techniques have revolutionized our understanding of solar radio emission, providing unprecedented insights into the complex dynamics of the solar corona and flares. This review synthesizes the latest findings from high-resolution observations, revealing intricate relationships between radio radiation, coronal structures, and magnetic field configurations. We discuss how these observations have shed light on particle acceleration mechanisms during solar flares and the propagation of energetic particles through the corona. The paper highlights the role of imaging spectroscopy in identifying fine-scale structures within radio sources, enabling more accurate mapping of magnetic field topologies. Furthermore, we explore how these new data have improved our ability to forecast space weather events and their potential impact on Earth. The integration of radio observations with multi-wavelength data from other instruments has led to a more comprehensive understanding of solar phenomena, paving the way for future research directions in solar physics and space weather prediction.
